description:
Somewhat based on the real story of how Gainax was founded, Otaku no Video addresses all aspects of an otaku lifestyle. Ken Kubo is a young man living an average life until he is dragged into a group of otaku. Slowly, he becomes more like them until he decides to abandon his former life to become king of otaku —the otaking!

Mixed in are live-action interviews with real otaku, addressing every aspect of hardcore otaku life. Not only are anime and manga fans included, but also sci-fi fans, military fans, and other groups of Japanese geeks.

tags.name: Otaku Culture
tags.description: Centers around the culture of a fanatical fan-base.

tags.name: Meta
tags.description: Features fourth wall-breaking references to itself or genre tropes.

tags.name: Philosophy
tags.description: Relating or devoted to the study of the fundamental nature of knowledge, reality, and existence.

tags.name: Hikikomori
tags.description: Prominently features a character who withdraws from social life, often seeking extreme isolation.

tags.name: Parody
tags.description: Features deliberate exaggeration of popular tropes or a particular genre to comedic effect.

tags.name: Historical
tags.description: Partly or completely set during a real period of world history.

tags.name: Primarily Adult Cast
tags.description: Main cast is mostly composed of characters above a high school age.

tags.name: Cosplay
tags.description: Features dressing up as a different character or profession.

tags.name: Educational
tags.description: Primary aim is to educate the audience.

tags.name: Time Skip
tags.description: Features a gap in time used to advance the story.

tags.name: Magic
tags.description: Prominently features magical elements or the use of magic.

title.native: DAICONⅢ オープニングアニメ

node.description:
[Twitter](https://twitter.com/moritakeshi)

Son of the baseball player Tooru Mori.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/757550602180173824)

Sonoda moved to Tokyo in 1984 and joined the animation studio [Artmic](https://anilist.co/studio/72/). There he worked as a designer for titles such as [Gall Force](https://anilist.co/anime/2060/) and [Bubblegum Crisis](https://anilist.co/anime/1347/). He left Artmic in 1991 and began work on his manga, [Gunsmith Cats](https://anilist.co/manga/31319/), which remains as his best known work to this day receiving both Harvey and Tezuka Award nominations.

He also has a deep knowledge of firearms.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/kenokun)

Kouhei attended Tokyo National University of Fine Arts and Music (Music Faculty, Composition Department), studying under Tomojirou Ikenouchi and other professors. He worked for three consecutive years at Victor Music Industries after he graduated from the University. He attended Berklee College of Music for two years after he left Victor Music Industries. After returning to Japan, Kouhei started his activities as a composer.

Though Kouhei had been playing at the hotel at first, he was requested to compose an insert song for "Arcadia of My Youth: Endless Orbit SSX", a 1982 TV anime, and it became his first work as a composer. Afterwards, he handled some more compositions of insert songs, this time for the Super Sentai series and he also did the composition of the background music for a TV anime, Konpora Kid, in 1985.

Notably, the score for [Top wo Nerae! Gunbuster](https://anilist.co/anime/949/) made his name and talent very famous among anime fans, and is recognized as one of his most important works. He also handled the composition of [Top wo Nerae 2! Diebuster](https://anilist.co/anime/1002/) and showed a peculiar arrangement, which he added to his previous 17-year-old work. Another of his most important work is often said to be [Yuusha-Ou GaoGaiGar](https://anilist.co/anime/890/), and the [sequel](https://anilist.co/anime/1382/) following it.

In 2002, he won the first Tokyo Anime Award for Best Music for his work on [Overman King Gainer](https://anilist.co/anime/1792/).
[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/鶴巻和哉)

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/本田雄)

After dropping out from Tokyo Designers' College in 1987, Honda joined Atelier Giga. He later joined [Gainax](https://anilist.co/studio/6/), where he debuted as the studio's youngest animation director on [Nadia: The Secret of Blue Water](https://anilist.co/anime/1251/). A few years later in 1994, he got to handle the character designs for the first time on [Metal Fighter Miku](https://anilist.co/anime/1175/), a TV series directed by [Akiyuki Shinbou](https://anilist.co/staff/100089/).

After having left Gainax, Honda participated in most of [Satoshi Kon](https://anilist.co/staff/99580/)'s works. Perhaps most notably as a character designer on [Millenium Actress](https://anilist.co/anime/1033/), a role which was originally planned to be [Hideki Hamasu](https://anilist.co/staff/125820/)'s, but was given to him due to Hamasu having contracted a severe tendon inflammation. Honda also designed the characters for [Mitsuo Iso](https://anilist.co/staff/100151/)'s [Dennou Coil](https://anilist.co/anime/2164/).

In 2006, Honda joined [Studio Khara](https://anilist.co/studio/47/) and reprised his vital staff roles in the [Evangelion](https://anilist.co/anime/2759/) franchise. The same year he made his long-awaited debut in a [Studio Ghibli](https://anilist.co/studio/21/) film, working as a key animator on [Tales from Earthsea](https://anilist.co/anime/1829/) and then again on [Ponyo](https://anilist.co/anime/2890/). His work received high praise by [Hayao Miyazaki](https://anilist.co/staff/96870/) for expressing the characters' individuality through their movements.

Nicknamed as "Master" (師匠, Shishou), by [Takahiro Kishida](https://anilist.co/staff/101403/) during the production of [Bubblegum Crisis](https://anilist.co/anime/1347/). Since then the nickname has been widely recognized within the industry.
[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/菊地康仁)

__Nickname:__ オタキング (Otaking)

[YouTube](https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC0FFHRF1mytLDhs6nxqGIQg) | [niconico](https://ch.nicovideo.jp/ex) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/ToshioOkada) | [Facebook](https://www.facebook.com/frex.otaking) | [Official Blog](http://blog.livedoor.jp/okada_toshio/) | [Profile (Yoshimoto Kogyo)](https://profile.yoshimoto.co.jp/talent/detail?id=3516) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Toshio_Okada) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E5%B2%A1%E7%94%B0%E6%96%97%E5%8F%B8%E5%A4%AB)

Okada Toshio is an anime producer, author, lecturer and the co-founder and former president of Gainax, which he left in 1992. He has written several Japanese-language books on otaku culture and lectured on the topic as an adjunct instructor at Tokyo University. He is considered the foremost authority on otaku and has been crowned "OtaKing" amongst his colleagues and fellow otaku.

(Source: AniDB)

He currently runs a popular YouTube channel [OTAKING](https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC0FFHRF1mytLDhs6nxqGIQg) discussing otaku culture. He runs weekly paid seminars on his NicoNico & YouTube channels.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/213956842)

Affiliated with [Studio Khara](https://anilist.co/studio/47/).
[Twitter](https://twitter.com/nagairumiko)

Affiliated with [Studio Khara](https://anilist.co/studio/47/) at the time of his passing.

After some time with Studio Giants at the beginning of his career in the early '80s, he went freelance. In 1984, he served as an assistant animation director on [Macross: Do You Remember Love?](https://anilist.co/anime/1089/). During the film's production, he met [Hideaki Anno](https://anilist.co/staff/100111/), who had just moved to Tokyo. Masuo and Anno quickly became friends and established Studio Graviton together with their fellow colleagues [Katsuhiko Nishijima](https://anilist.co/staff/103059/) and [Kouji Itou](https://anilist.co/staff/101166/). At Graviton, Masuo came to the limelight as the mechanical animation director on [Project A-Ko](https://anilist.co/anime/212/).

After Graviton, he moved to [Gainax](https://anilist.co/studio/6/), where he worked as an assistant director for [Royal Space Force](https://anilist.co/anime/1034/), and as a unit director on [Gunbuster](https://anilist.co/anime/949/). Through the '90s and early '00s, Masuo served as a key staff member in many of Gainax's works until moving to Studio Khara in 2006.

He passed away from an undisclosed illness on July 24, 2017.

(Source: Wikipedia)

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/藤山房伸)

The representative director of Jinnan Studio.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/murahama)

After graduating from school he took social sciences at Otemon Gakuin University, where he belonged to the local SF club. During his time at university he participated in Daicon Film activities and after dropping out of university in 1987 he joined the former Daicon Film, now Gainax, where he participated as Production Manager in works such as Honneamise, Nadia and Top wo Nerae.

In 1992 he left together with Maeda Mahiro, Higuchi Shinji and Yamaguchi Hiroshi to establish a new studio, Gonzo, where he assumed the position of President and Representative Director. Currently he serves as Chairman of the Board and Representative Director at GDH.

Murahama left Gonzo on March 31, 2009 and launched a new company called Lambda Film on April 1, 2009, the same day that Gozo's parent company, GDH, absorbed Gonzo and adopted the Gonzo brand name for itself.

Murahama will serve as the representative director for Lambda Film's board of directors.

__Nickname:__ オタキング (Otaking)

[YouTube](https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC0FFHRF1mytLDhs6nxqGIQg) | [niconico](https://ch.nicovideo.jp/ex) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/ToshioOkada) | [Facebook](https://www.facebook.com/frex.otaking) | [Official Blog](http://blog.livedoor.jp/okada_toshio/) | [Profile (Yoshimoto Kogyo)](https://profile.yoshimoto.co.jp/talent/detail?id=3516) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Toshio_Okada) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E5%B2%A1%E7%94%B0%E6%96%97%E5%8F%B8%E5%A4%AB)

Okada Toshio is an anime producer, author, lecturer and the co-founder and former president of Gainax, which he left in 1992. He has written several Japanese-language books on otaku culture and lectured on the topic as an adjunct instructor at Tokyo University. He is considered the foremost authority on otaku and has been crowned "OtaKing" amongst his colleagues and fellow otaku.

(Source: AniDB)

He currently runs a popular YouTube channel [OTAKING](https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC0FFHRF1mytLDhs6nxqGIQg) discussing otaku culture. He runs weekly paid seminars on his NicoNico & YouTube channels.
The founder and representative director of Studio Tulip.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/fantasia_iizuka)

Tomohisa Iizuka is a producer and planner for anime. He served as the representative director of Studio Fantasia until it went bankrupt in 2016. Before that he worked in the finishing section of Tsuchida Production as colour designer.

Iizuka founded the animation company Studio Fantasia, when he was still an employee of Tsuchida Production, on October 12, 1983 which was three years before Tsuchida Production collapsed into bankruptcy.
Sadafumi Sano is a director of photography.

Yoshimi Kanda is a pen name of Hiroshi Ueda, a former employee of General Products and studio Gainax.

Originally, he was a member of the Kagawa University Sci-Fi Club. His connections in doujinshi circles paved his way to General Products. He later organized the magazine Cyber Comic and served as editor-in-chief. He left General Products after company cutbacks did away with its editorial department.

As a member of Gainax, he took on different roles when working on the shows produced by the studio. The anime where he arguably made the largest contribution was Otaku no Video: he was a producer, the director of the live-action segments, and also the author of the lyrics to the opening and ending songs.

Besides anime production, he was also involved in video game development. In particular, he wrote the scenario for Sega platformer Alisia Dragoon, which was co-developed by Gainax and Game Arts, and created the original concept design for SNES action platformer Xardion, which had Gainax listed in the credits as providing development and planning assistance.
Yuuko Asai is a music director.

__Hometown:__ Tokyo, Japan 

Toshiharu Sakurai is a Japanese voice actor who works for 81 Produce. He is the official Japanese dubbing voice for Shaggy Rogers in the Scooby-Doo franchise.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/kenokun)

Kouhei attended Tokyo National University of Fine Arts and Music (Music Faculty, Composition Department), studying under Tomojirou Ikenouchi and other professors. He worked for three consecutive years at Victor Music Industries after he graduated from the University. He attended Berklee College of Music for two years after he left Victor Music Industries. After returning to Japan, Kouhei started his activities as a composer.

Though Kouhei had been playing at the hotel at first, he was requested to compose an insert song for "Arcadia of My Youth: Endless Orbit SSX", a 1982 TV anime, and it became his first work as a composer. Afterwards, he handled some more compositions of insert songs, this time for the Super Sentai series and he also did the composition of the background music for a TV anime, Konpora Kid, in 1985.

Notably, the score for [Top wo Nerae! Gunbuster](https://anilist.co/anime/949/) made his name and talent very famous among anime fans, and is recognized as one of his most important works. He also handled the composition of [Top wo Nerae 2! Diebuster](https://anilist.co/anime/1002/) and showed a peculiar arrangement, which he added to his previous 17-year-old work. Another of his most important work is often said to be [Yuusha-Ou GaoGaiGar](https://anilist.co/anime/890/), and the [sequel](https://anilist.co/anime/1382/) following it.

In 2002, he won the first Tokyo Anime Award for Best Music for his work on [Overman King Gainer](https://anilist.co/anime/1792/).

Kouji Tsujitani was a Japanese actor, voice actor, narrator, and director of audiography. Tsujitani used to be affiliated with Sigma Seven. He died of a stroke on October 17, 2018.

He was married to fellow voice actress [Kumiko Watanabe](https://anilist.co/staff/95248/).

[Website](https://www.manbow.com/) | [Profile](http://office-anemone.com/mt-search.cgi?IncludeBlogs=4,5&tag=井上喜久子) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/atmanbow_staff)

Mother of voice actress [Honoka Inoue](https://anilist.co/staff/129363/Honoka-Inoue). She has held a long-running gag of being 'eternally 17 years old'.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/360426889) | [Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/ikurovski/) | [Youtube](https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCCdY-XhRirjjUDEInOYVyCw) | [Website](https://ikuro1960.com)
